Interface Tag

All Known Subinterfaces:
ContinuousTag
All Known Implementing Classes:
TagCase, TagReset, TagSpecialCharacters
public interface Tag
Tags are elements one can use inside of strings to change parts of that string easily. Some examples of valid tags and their behaviour:
  • <yellow>, <reset>: singleton tags, no parameters
  • <case=uppercase>, <color=#ffffff: parameter tags, one parameter
  • <link=text,link.to.my/image.png>: plural tags, multiple parameters
  • &r: short tags, no parameters
Note that you can use a backslash ('\') to escape characters inside tags.
See Also:
  • TagReset
  • TagCase

  • Method Details

    • init

      boolean init(String key, String[] parameters)
      Initialises this Tag before being used. This method is always called before all the others in an extending class.
      Parameters:
      key - the key that was matched. Note that this can be a single character used in a short tag (like &r).
      parameters - an array of strings representing all the parameters that are being passed to this syntax element. Elements of this array can't be null or empty.
      Returns:
      true if the tag was initialized successfully, false otherwise. A good practice is to check for the array length of the parameters to not interfere with other addons.

    • getValue

      String getValue(String affected)
      Returns a string applied by this tag.
      Parameters:
      affected - the string this tags affects.
      Returns:
      the applied string

    • toString

      String toString(boolean debug)

    • isUsable

      default boolean isUsable(String tagCtx)
      Check if this tag is usable in a certain tag context. The default context is 'default'.
      Parameters:
      tagCtx - the tag context
      Returns:
      whether or not this tag is usable in this context, default true for every context

    • combinesWith

      default boolean combinesWith(Class<? extends Tag> tag)
      Some tags can stack on top of each other. A perfect example would be Markdown, where one can make a text both bold and italics at the same time. If this tag can complement such tag, you should define it here.

      Most of the times, you want a two-way connection, for example: bold combines with italics and vice-versa.

      Parameters:
      tag - the tag
      Returns:
      whether or not this tag can complement the given tag
